document.text: with the assistance of Common wealth Attorney Isbell. 4e found John tending his garden and spent the still, hot summer afternoon of July 2 held fast by our imagination, talking with this quiet man. We followed him in to another time as surely as H. G. Wells could take us. I admit to being more than just an interested visitor to our historical parks, and for this reason I am perhaps more crit ical of how they are interpret ed. However, I am typical of most visitors in one important respect rarely does history be come an emotional rather than intellectual experience for the thoroughly urbanized visitor. John Howard is real to my wife and me. He is real to the other visitors who stood in the heat of a July afternoon and talked with a man in homespun wool who told us why and how he followed Virginia into war. Per haps such insights may be thought irrelevant when many  other things seem so pressing, I

Parrish, born in Cumberland county in 1829, came to this co unty when a young man and began the practice of law. and soon his ability was recognized and he was made judge, and filled the office with ability until 1889 when he re signed .to practice law in the o!ty of Roanoke, where he passed away in 1913. document.text: was with him.on one occasion when he was calling on a lady, Miss Jennie Harris. A thunder storm had come up and Miss Jennie was terribly afraid of lightening. She occupied a short sofa with Isbell. After a loud clap of thunder and a vivid flash of lightening she involuntarily sprang a bit nearer to Isbell. With his characteristic humor he replied. Set up close, stick to me Miss Jennie I ant the best lightening rod you ever saw. Then there was Oakville with its tall lombardy popular trees. This was the residence and store of the late Bryant Nowlin, the father of John, William C., and S. W. Nowlin. He always wore a daw-hemmer broad cloth coat and a beaver hat with a flowing wig. I can recall him as he attended court with his red leather saddle-bags filled with store accounts, swinging over his left arm and his right  hand resting under th e ! claw-hammer coattail. A little northwest of Oakville stands the old Red Oak j ChurchJHere the good Baptists for miles around assembled to 1 ehar Old parson Sam Davidson preach. It was with a feeling of sadness that last summer I drove over to my grandfathers  old place. I stood at the door front and back, where the grass now comes to the steps and recalled my youthful visits there, when the space under the mulberry tree at the front and the grand old oak at the  back door was a nice marble  yard. I drove over to the new Courthouse in Appomattox, now quite a town with one or two well-kept hotels, a livery stable, and quite a number of stores and handsome residenc es. I recalled how I stood with others on the side of the railroad track - with all around then in original forests - side of I drove over to the new Courthouse in Appomattox, now quite a town with one or  two well-kept hotels, a livery i stable, and quite a number of  stores and handsome residenc- Isbell, long while an attorney I es. I recalled how I stood with for the Commonwealth. Warm-j hearted, and genial, a better j man never lived with it he i possessed a vein of wit-hand , humor that made him aj welcome guest in any home and i the center of every circule. I j

document.text: Valuable publicity for Appo mattox has been the result of featur ed material in the current issue of Transgas, the splendid monthly magazine of Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation, with principal offices in Houston, Texas. Ken B. Harper is editor of Transgas. He was in Appomattox recently and gathered pictures and material for the article which will advertise Appomattox over a vast area of Eastern Ameri ca served by Transcontinental. The magazine has high rating as an in dustrial publication. The front cover of the current is sue pictures Otis P. Dewberry, Supt. adjusting one of the big valves on the gas-cooler at Transcos Station 17 at Appomattox. The back cover of the magazine shows the residence of Mrs. F. C. Dresser inAppomattox. Subject of the featured material is,  88 Years Later, referring to the fact that Appomattox is thriving 88 years after the peace made in 1865. The inside front cover shows a full page picture of the McLean House. The historical story begins on Page 5, with a full page drawing of Lee and Grant shaking hands in re- concialation. There follows a well- written account of. the events of the April, 1865 peace-making. Page 8 comes up with a full page of Editor Calvin Robinson in his office at the Times-Virginian .plant, There follow many pages about the operations of Transcontinental in Appomattox and commentary on the thriving economy of the modern community 88 Years Later. Pictures include Engineer Lloyd Bryant at a spotless auxiliary unit a scene of Transco housing at Dewberry Hill  the Patteson - Hix Tavern Farmers National Bank and Bank of Appomax, Mauds Hot Shop, the Bocock - Isbell House Appomattox Garment Co., Inc. R. L. McIntyre runnning a chemical test at Station 17 the New Appomattox Court House A. G. Thompson and Hanley Phelps on a mechanical job at Station 17 5 a view of the Confed erate Cemetery Billy Pettet, radio technician at Station 17 Robert M. Honeycutt, foreman of Crew 3, PL. Dist. 7 and a two-page panoramic picture of Station 17 itself. The read ing material features interviews on modern Appomattox, with W. W. Burke, T. DeWitt Evans, R. B. Hud gins, Editor Robinson and others. Since the issue of Transgas has been received here, local comment has been that it is one of the best prepared and best written features yet to appear on Appomattox. Copies of the issue were given the National Dark Service officials, Major-General U. S. Grant, III, Rev. Richard Lee, and other distinguished guests here ii Tuesday for the premiere of Sunset at Appomattox.

The first passenger train roing through to Roanoke was in November, 1852. This, of ourse, was a great boon to the transportation and development lf the County. At that time the engines were fired with wood cut, hauled and stacked along the track. I The New Constitution above referred to, provided for the election of officers by a vote of the people, rather than by ap- Pointment, and in May of that year the first election was held.  1 I860 Geo. T. Peers became the County Clerk, Wilson BHix, Sheriff, Samuel J. Walker Commissioner of the Revenue, l and L. D. Isbell, Commonwealth Attorney. It was a time marked by great national issues and fateful  visions. document.text: The Ladies Aid Society of Trinity church met with a picnic dinner at the home of Mr. J. B. Whitehead on Saturday, August 4tli, and celebrated his mother, Mrs. Lucy A. Whiteheads 92nd birthday. There were 66 pres ent and four generations were represented in two families. In the afternoon there was much music and singing, which was greatly enjoyed by all, especial ly the older ones, who are not able to get around much. The many friends of Mr. S. R. Martin will be glad to know that he attended Sunday School Sun day for the first time since his illness and operation. We are glad to report that Mrs. T. M. Taylor is much im proved and attended the revival at Trinity one night also picnic at Mrs. Whiteheads. Mrs. A. F. Drinkard and daughter, Louise, were over this week to see Miss Lina Carson, who has been quite sick. They report she is much better. Messrs. A. B. and E. L. Chick lad as their guests this week their sister, Mrs. A. F. Drink ard and daughter, Louise. The revival recently held at Trinity church, conducted by Rev. D. G. Trent, of Appomat tox, was much enjoyed and we feel the community as weH as the church was benefited by the sermons so ably delivered. An Epworth League has re cently been organized at Trinity church which we hope will be a great help to the community. Mr. T. M. Martin accompan ied some of his friends to Nor folk last week-end. Mr. Milton Isbell looks quite sporty driving around in his new Dodge. There will be a lawn party at Trinity church Saturday, August 18th, beginning at 5 oclock. Dont forget the date. Every- body invited. ------------ o ------------

document.text: The following write up about a former resident of Appomattox co unty appeared in the Washington Herald last week. The ability to tell a good story well is without question an incom parable social asset. Such talent is the undisputed possession of D . D. Isbell, Interstate Commerce Commis sion, who can generally tell you one you never heard before and relate even the better known ones in a manner more amusing than just about anyone else you might know. According to the Arabian Knights, ability to tell the worlds longest story is said to have saved the life of Queen Scheherazade, whose task was just about as difficult as her name. Genial Mr.Isbell would not think of trying to capture the royal I- dys crown for extended anecdote, lie prefers rather to encompass a great deal of significence in few words. In a world of rather serious outlook, especially at this time Mr. Isbell is performing a real service for humanity in his ability to make foiks smile, His motto, as you may well .surmise is Laugh and the world laughts with you. M r. Isbell is a nephew of the late M r. Milton Isbell, who recently died in Lynchburg, a Civil War veteran and is well knowm here. He is also Master of a Masonic Lodge in Washington.

document.text: The constitution of the organiza tion of the farmers of Prince Ed ward and Cumberland was read, and a committee was raised to examine and remodel it fov the use of the Appomattox Institute. In view of the stated meeting of these organizations at Farmvillc on Saturday, for the purpose of per fecting a state organization, the Ap pomattox Institute elected the fol lowing delegates to attend Miiton Isbell, J. W. Gilliam. J. Ii. Caldwell, J. R. Horseley, J. W. Flood aud H. C. Babcock. Major Flood attended the Farm- ville meeting and reports that the state organization was deferred, but that a committee was appointed to diaft a state constitution, and that the state organization will be per fected later. The Appomattox Institute ad journed to meet Thursday after first Monday in May. We shall be glad to see the farm ers of Appomattox thoroughly or ganized.

document.text: The colored people of our com munity, on Monday last, were hold ing a fair at Galilee. Refreshments were served and many goods were be sold at auction. - Every one eemed to be in a good humor and Jhe day seemed destined to pass off -fith success and profit. But, un- 1 ortunately for our law-abiding col- i red citizens many of the young qnen of that race imbibed too freely 4n the morning, and, feeling pretty jolly, determined on making the fair at Galilee a vent for their serperflu- ous mirth. So, in a crowd, they re sorted thither. The exercises had commenced, as near as we can learn, abont 1 1 oclock, and the young men arrived about a half hour after that time. As soon as they reached the scene of festivities they began picking fusses with those present, and try ing in every way to disturb the peace. From small beginnings the trouble gradually increased until it grew into a general scrimmage. Indeed it was hard to tell who was impli cated aud who was not. Rocks were thrown at the church and several pistols were fired. 1 Women rushed from the building and for a time it seemed as if pandemonium was turn ed loose. The main ring-leaders seem to have been, Albert Walker, Doug Watkins, Chas. Sears, Samuel Johns, Jr., Alex. Christian, John McReynolds, Jesse Turner and Har vey Coleman. , Warrants were issued for the ar rest of the above, and on Tuesday, they were brought before Justice of the Peace Durrum. The firstprisoner tried was Chas. Wright but as there was au insufficiency of evidence, he was released. v He fired a pistol, it is true, but apparently did it out of a spirit of fun and not with any evil intent. Albert Walker was the next pris oner called, and from the evidence deduced he was evidently very nnjcb concerned in the disorderly proceed ings. Albert seems to have been partic ularly conspicuou s in starting the row. As one of the witnesses said, Al bert was exposed dat away any how, an as he was pretty high up he couldnt bate him down. Several of the men had been en deavoring to throw Sam Johns down upon the benches, but had not suc- ueeded, when Albert, rushing up, seized Sam threw him down and ex claimed, no mattah how long de legs is, devse boun to come wheu Im thar. Doug Watsons chief offense was thiowing rocks inside the church. He rushed in at the door with a handful of rocks and without hesitat ing let them fly at the assembled crowd. He threw three timeB and twice his aim proved true, falling with dire, effect upon the heads of two young men. Some say that Doug repeated this outrage, hut it was not introduced into the evidence. The only personal difficulty that occurred was between Archer Wal ker and Charlie Sears. The former claims that Sears struck him on the head with a rock and for that reason he pommelled him with a stick. Sears, however, reached for another rock and soon had Uncle Archer in full flight for the church, where, by the aid of several of the women, he was concealed beneath a staircase until the fracas had subsided. Some evidence was introduced tending to show that Sears was first struck by Walker but, in spite of that, it is generally believed that he Sears was one of the prime causes of the whole disturbance. Samuel Johns, Jr., when brought up for trial, was shown to have been j ust as guilty as any of them. His brother, Lawson Isbell, did all in his power to restrain him but to no pur pose. The evidence of Lawson Isbell against his own brother was surpris ingly intelligent, being clear, logical and honest. Alex. Christian seems to have ren dered himself surprisingly obnoxious. As one of the wituesses testified be made everything all into a gangle. The difficulty must have lasted about five hours, and how the re spectable and law-abiding colored people could have submitted to it as long as they did, is Something as tonishing. We are told that this sort of thing has been going on for seven or eight years, and that finally it became so unbearable that the members of Galilee Church were forced to have recourse to the law. The action of the witnesses and of those who caused the arrest is highly commendable, and should be met with hearty approbation from every white man in the county. The

document.text: The Appomattox chapter of the  Daughters of the Confederacy held its annual Memorial Day program at tile Conferedate .Cemetery last Saturday afternoon. Flags and be autiful flowers sent by the garden club decorated the graves. J.A . Burke was chairman for the j occasion. Miss M. Anna Jones, the  president of the chapter introduced j the chairman. Joel W.Flood made the address. He gave a resume of  the plans for the park at the old court house and plans for the res toration o f. the area as it was at the time of the Surrender.He made a plea to all who had property in the proposed park area to cooperate with the government in making the land immediately .available. Miss Mary Louise Gills had charge of  the memorial honoring Samuel M. I Ranson and Milton Isbell, two vet erans who died during the past year . 1

Our soldiers have all returned from the reunion held at Char lotte, N- C. last week- Those able to attend were Goe. W. Cheatham, C. H. Coeman, Chas. W. Cardwell, Thomas Marsh, John OBrien and Milton Isbell. They report a very pleasant trip and a happy reunion with about 2500 in attendance. Friends and citizens who de sire to see thje Garment Plant in operation are invited to do so this week, after which the plant will be closed to visitors. About 30 machines are now in operation.
